Fig. 1 (a) Schematic diagram of preparation of the PdAu@CTF Catalyst. (b) TEM image of the Pd0.6Au0.4@CTF catalyst. (c) HR-TEM image of the Pd0.6Au0.4@CTF catalyst. (d) Lattice fringe pattern of PdAu alloy NCs after FFT. (e) HAADF–STEM image of the Pd0.6Au0.4@CTF catalyst. (f) EDS elemental maps of C, N, Pd, and Au in the Pd0.6Au0.4@CTF catalyst. (g) Representative EDS line scan profiles of a single PdAu NC taken in the STEM mode. (h) Volume of released gas versus time for FA dehydrogenation for PdAu@CTF with distinct Pd/Au molar compositions without additive at 333 K. (i) PdAu@CTF catalyzes the corresponding TOF value [59]. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Schematic diagram of common carrier materials used in heterogeneous catalytic hydrogen production of formic acid. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Flowchart of carrier modification strategies. (a) Schematic illustration of the preparation of the Pdlr/SBA-15NH2 NCS [89]. (b) A schematic illustration of the preparation of Pd/NH2-CNT [83]. (c) The general synthetic process of Pd/NBF-C catalyst [34]. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Pd-Ag catalytic model image. (b) SEM and TEM images of PdAg@Pd ONCs. (c) Hydrogen-producing activity of catalyst. (d) H2 production rates of PdAg@Pd ONCs with different Pd shell. (e) H2 production rates and corresponding TOF values of Pd3.5Ag@Pd1.1 L ONCs [100]. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Calculated potential energy diagram (PED) for the H2 production from the HCOOH decomposition on the Pd (111) surface in pathway II (the solid green line). The dotted red line means the potential energy change for the HCOO− → CO2 (g) + H− reaction. The values in PED indicate the activation energies (which are given in eV) in each reaction step. Molecular configurations of reactant state, transition state (TS) and product state in each reaction step. The big gray, brown, red, and small white balls represent Pd, C, O, and H atoms, respectively [107]. Hydrogen is a renewable energy carrier and one of the most competitive fuel options for the future. Formic acid, due to its high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen capacities (4.4 wt% and 53 g H2·L−1), is a viable hydrogen carrier. Formic acid can undergo hydrogen release and storage reactions when subjected to suitable catalysts. This paper reviews heterogeneous catalysts for the dehydrogenation of formic acid, focusing on catalyst modification, catalyst deactivation, and the reaction mechanism of formic acid. The modification strategies enhance catalyst performance by influencing catalyst size, composition, and electronic configuration through synergistic effects between metals and interactions between the support and the metal. The active sites are blocked by CO produced from side reactions, leading to catalyst poisoning. By adding Mo and altering the reaction alkalinity, CO production can be reduced, thereby preventing catalyst poisoning. Currently, there are two main mechanisms for formic acid decomposition. One mechanism involves adsorption and decomposition via the formate anion. The other involves decomposition and reorganization through a formic acid ester intermediate. This review summarizes the research progress on heterogeneous catalysts and suggests that Mo2C catalysts should be a focus for further study. Graphical Abstract Keywords Formic acid decomposition Hydrogen Heterogeneous catalyst Catalyst deactivation Decomposition mechanism Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Currently, about 90 % of the world's energy supply comes from fossil fuels. In light of the depletion of fossil fuels and the increase in global energy consumption, there is an urgent need for alternative and sustainable energy sources [1]. Hydrogen is regarded as a promising energy carrier due to its high energy density and clean combustion properties [2]. Currently, there are multiple methods used for hydrogen production [3]. Hydrogen production using renewable energy sources is an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly method that has garnered widespread attention [4]. The transportation and storage of H₂ present challenges due to its flammability and high reactivity [5]. In order to solve this problem, formic acid (FA) can be used as a carrier for H2 storage. In the presence of catalysts, FA can be decomposed into H2 and CO2. People also focus on developing efficient catalysts to promote formic acid decomposition (FAD) for H2 production [6,7]. FA as a hydrogen carrier offers the following advantages: high gravimetric (4.4 wt%) and volumetric (53.4 g/L) H2 capacity [8,9]. At present, the most popular methods of producing FA are catalytic hydrolysis/oxidation of biomass and CO2 hydrogenation [10]. There have been many reports on FAD. FA is a viable hydrogen carrier. The reaction direction is influenced by the catalyst. In the presence of a catalyst, FA can effectively decompose into H2 and CO2 without causing adverse environmental impacts [11]. Currently, the reaction of CO₂ with H₂ to produce FA is a commonly used method that can effectively reduce the environmental impact of CO₂ [12]. In recent years, scientists have made great efforts to find efficient catalysts for FAD [13]. Research on homogeneous catalysts has focused on the noble metals ruthenium (Rh) and iridium (Ir) [14]. Homogeneous catalysts have high reaction activity but come with some drawbacks in practical applications. The use of homogeneous catalysts presents challenges in terms of separating and recovering additives, as well as disposing of used catalysts. Thus, the exploration of high-performance heterogeneous catalysts has become a priority [15]. A significant number of studies on heterogeneous catalysts have been conducted, with particular focus on palladium (Pd), gold (Au), silver (Ag), and platinum (Pt), which have garnered considerable attention. Test results indicate that noble metal catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance [16]. As research has progressed, there has been significant investigation into the decomposition mechanism of FA [17]. In the pursuit of higher-performance catalysts, it has been found that the metal dispersion, specific surface area, and particle size are key factors determining catalyst performance [18]. Therefore, some modification strategies have been applied to catalysts. The performance of the catalyst is significantly improved [19]. At present, non-noble metals are also being explored as active components of catalysts. Bulushev et al. [20] tried using non-noble metals as catalysts for FAD, with transition metals such as nickel (Ni), molybdenum carbide (Mo2C), copper (Cu) and cobalt (Co) receiving a lot of attention. Li et al. tried to use cobalt and copper as catalysts for FAD [21]. Bulushev et al. [22] have reviewed single metal atomic catalysts. One point is that copper catalysts are seldom reported due to poor catalytic performance. In recent years, Zhang et al. have reported their copper catalysts using carbon nitride as the carrier [23]. Li et al. reported the successful preparation of copper single-atom catalyst. This catalyst possesses excellent catalytic performance [24]. Modification strategies for noble metal catalysts have also been applied to non-noble metal catalysts. Modified catalysts exhibit excellent performance not only in FAD but also in processes such as dry reforming of methane, steam reforming of methanol, and electrocatalysis [18,25,26]. This paper reviews the progress of research on heterogeneous catalysts for FAD. This paper primarily reviews noble metal catalysts such as palladium, gold, and platinum catalysts, as well as non-noble metal catalysts such as nickel, copper, and cobalt catalysts. It summarizes the methods for modifying catalyst performance, such as using a second metal, modifying the carrier, structural optimization, and promoter strategies. The FA conversion, H2 selectivity, and service life of the modified catalyst are also reviewed. Additionally, this paper briefly describes the causes of catalyst deactivation and provides an overview of the reaction mechanism of FA over the catalyst. Finally, the FAD catalysts are summarized and discussed, and the prospect for FAD catalysts are expected. 2 Noble metal catalysts At present, noble metal catalysts mainly include palladium, gold, silver and platinum. Palladium-based catalysts are generally considered to be the most active catalysts for hydrogen production from FA. Palladium-based catalysts are used in both the liquid-phase and gas-phase decomposition of FA [14]. The selection of the reaction system considers factors such as catalyst formulation, reaction mechanism, and side reactions. For example, Pd-based catalysts have a small atomic radius, enabling the effective utilization of surface atoms in liquid-phase reaction. The d-electron orbitals of palladium are in an unfilled state, which gives it strong coordination ability at moderate temperatures, thereby promoting electron transfer during reactions. Porous structured carriers and widely applied amine-functionalized carriers are designed to make these catalysts suitable for liquid-phase reaction. Additionally, in liquid-phase reaction systems, sodium formate and water are commonly added as additives and solvents. According to the Le Chatelier's principle, the addition of water hinders the dehydration of FA, favoring the dehydrogenation of FA. FA transitions to a gaseous state above 373 K, and as a result, some catalysts are also used in gas-phase reaction. Metal nanoparticles uniformly distributed on the carrier surface ensure maximum contact with gaseous FA, enabling a more complete reaction. The gas-phase reaction of the hydrogen production is energetically favorable and exothermic, while other reactions are endothermic and less favorable. Although side reactions may occur at high temperatures, some modified catalysts can achieve CO-free production, making them suitable for gas-phase reaction. The catalytic performance of catalysts is mainly affected by metal dispersion, surface area and particle size [27]. Noble metal catalysts for FAD are listed in Table 1 and Table 2. 2.1 Catalyst modification strategy 2.1.1 Bimetallic strategy The addition of a metal can modify the alloy structure and particle size of the catalyst nanoparticles, thereby affecting its performance [53]. In order to improve the performance of catalysts, a series of bimetallic catalysts have been reported, including gold–palladium [54–59], silver–palladium [60–64], cobalt–palladium [65], and copper–palladium [66,67]. Alloy catalysts are modified by adding metals into palladium catalysts. The strong intermetallic interactions enhance catalytic activity. It has been found that the activity of the catalyst increases with the increase of the gold component in the gold–palladium alloy catalyst. The study shows that the presence of gold affects the final particle size of the catalyst nanoparticles. The presence of gold leads to a reduction in catalyst particle size. This was also confirmed in the report by James Pritchard [68]. A series of characterization ( Fig. 1) confirms that the gold–palladium catalyst has a very small particle size. The catalytic performance is affected by the ratio of palladium to gold (Fig. 1h,i). It can be seen that the distribution of palladium is not affected by the presence of gold. In addition to using gold, researchers also use silver, with its similar properties, as a metal additive to modify palladium catalysts. Tsang et al. [69] reported on silver–palladium catalyst, confirming the feasibility of using silver as a second metal. Zhou's team deposited palladium on silver nanosheets and successfully prepared a series of silver–palladium catalysts. According to the test results, the turnover frequency (TOF) of the silver palladium catalyst with hexagonal close packed crystals reached 19,000 ± 1630 h−1 at 363 K. They found that the synergistic effect of palladium and silver led to the high activity of the catalyst [70]. Deng et al. [71] also confirmed that the particle size and metal dispersion of palladium catalysts are altered after silver doping. The bimetallic strategy enhances the adsorption of active sites through metal-metal interactions. This phenomenon is very interesting and worth further study. The effect of adding noble metals is significant. In recent years, catalysts composed of noble metals and transition metals have also been studied. Cobalt and copper are frequently used as second metals to modify catalysts. In 2022, Wu et al. [72] prepared bimetallic catalysts by doping cobalt into palladium-based catalysts. Experimental results show that the catalyst has good catalytic performance, with the TOF up to 8117 h−1 at 333 K. Centeno et al. [73] conducted a comparative test with cobalt doped catalysts and single metal catalysts without doping. It is found that the performance of cobalt–palladium catalysts was much better than that of single metal catalysts. In addition to the use of cobalt, studies investigate the potential of copper to significantly enhance catalytic activity. Mori et al. [74] found that doping copper into palladium catalysts can enhance the dissociation of C–H bond. The palladium–copper catalyst has higher efficiency and a longer service life than the ordinary palladium catalyst, due to its relatively strong ability to resist CO adsorption. Experimental results also proved that the service life of the copper–palladium catalyst is longer than that of the ordinary catalyst. It can be seen that non-noble metal doping can enhance metal dispersion and maintain a small metal particle size, thereby improving the performance of the catalyst. This provides a potential method for future research on high-performance catalysts. 2.1.2 Carrier modification strategy The performance of the catalyst is also affected by the carrier. The type of carrier affects the metal dispersion, specific surface area, and particle size of the catalyst nanoparticles. The metal-carrier interactions could also affect the performance of the catalyst [75–77]. Liu et al. [78] reported in detail the effect of the metal-carrier interactions on FAD. At present, carbon materials, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), resins and silica are often used as catalyst carriers. Fig. 2 summarizes the common types of metal carriers. 2.1.2.1 Carbon-based carrier At present, common carbon material carriers include activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, graphene, and carbon nanosheets [79,80]. Carbon-based catalysts with mesoporous structures can maintain metal nanoparticles within a narrow size distribution. Mori [81] et al. found that the Pd nanoparticles in the synthesized catalyst retain a size of 3.9 nm and are arranged in an orderly manner. Additionally, graphene has a sheet-like structure, which gives it a high specific surface area. Carbon nanotubes have a tubular structure, with a highly stable hollow interior. Yang et al. [82] found that when carbon nanotubes are used to support Pd, they not only confine Pd within the tubular structure but also induce a downward shift in the Pd d-band center, thereby promoting the reaction. In recent years, several modification strategies have been applied to carbon carriers. Doping nitrogen, oxygen, and other atoms to create specific defect structures is a common modification strategy. Treating carbon-based carriers with alkaline reagents during the preparation process can introduce various functional groups, giving the carbon-based carriers unique properties. For example, treating carbon nanomaterials with NaOH can result in the detection of C–O–Na functional groups on the surface. Chesnokov et al. [49] used graphene as a carrier and found that doping the carrier with nitrogen atoms forms a structure with defects that can stabilize platinum atoms on the graphene. In a recent research report, Podyacheva et al. prepared Pd/N-CNTs catalysts using nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes as carriers. The synthesized carrier exhibits the bamboo-like packing of graphene layers, a structure that enhances the formation of nitrogen defect sites, thereby improving the adhesion of Pd nanoparticles. Meanwhile, the amine functional groups distributed on the surface of the carbon nanotubes promote the cleavage of O-H bonds [43]. Kim et al. improved the hydrophobicity of carbon nanotubes by incorporating hydrophilic amine groups ( Fig. 3b) [83]. Carbon-based carriers are of particular interest due to their diversity. Leveraging the advantages of carbon-based carriers, a series of innovative modifications have been reported. These novel preparation methods have introduced unique structures that significantly enhance catalyst performance. 2.1.2.2 Resin-based carrier Resin as a carrier offers unique advantages. Firstly, it can withstand both strong acidic and basic environments, making it suitable for use in FAD. Resin possesses a high specific surface area, which facilitates the functionalization of its surface with various functional groups. Additionally, its pore size is adjustable, allowing for the preparation of micropores, mesopores, and macropores based on specific needs. Finally, some resins are biodegradable, contributing to environmental protection. Bhaumik et al. mentioned in their review of porous nanomaterials that porous resins can serve as carriers [84]. The most common method for modifying resin is grafting functional groups onto its surface. Mori et al. prepared catalysts using alkaline resin as a carrier [85]. The resin has a large reticulated structure with –N(CH3)2 groups that synergistically interact with the metal atoms. A large reticulated structure provides a high specific surface area, offering abundant active sites. The amine functional groups on the resin exhibit weak basicity, which promotes the FAD. In 2022, Li et al. used resin as a carrier to study the effects of three different functional groups on the reaction [86]. The results showed that the positively charged −N(CH₃)₃⁺ attracts the negatively charged HCOO⁻, leading to a localized increase in HCOO⁻ concentration, which facilitates the reaction. In summary, resin as a carrier possesses excellent properties and is easily modifiable. However, the current modification strategies for resin-based carriers are limited. Future research should focus on developing more effective modification techniques to further enhance the performance of resin-based carriers. 2.1.2.3 Silica-based carrier Silicon dioxide (SiO2) is a common inorganic material known for its unique spatial structure, high-temperature resistance, and corrosion resistance. Mesoporous silica, with its highly ordered mesoporous channels, offers a large surface area, high porosity, and adjustable pore sizes. These characteristics make it frequently used as a carrier in various applications. SBA-15 is one of the classic mesoporous silica materials, which was first synthesized and reported by Zhao et al. [87]. The mesoporous structure of silica allows for rapid diffusion upon contact with FA, thereby accelerating the reaction [88]. The surface Si-OH groups of silica can be readily modified with amine groups, and the interaction between silica and the metal during metal loading can also promote O-H bond cleavage. In 2019, Nie et al. used SiO2 as a carrier to prepare a catalyst. FA is completely converted on this catalyst [89]. The mesoporous structure of silica confines the size of metal nanoparticles to 1.1 nm and ensures high dispersion, maximizing the effectiveness of the active sites (Fig. 3a). In addition, many reports indicate that amine-functionalized mesoporous silica exhibits excellent performance [90–93]. The presence of amine groups imparts mild basicity to the carrier, enhancing the selectivity of active sites for HCOO⁻. Additionally, certain amine groups can function as active sites, contributing to the reaction. 2.1.2.4 Metal-organic framework-based carrier MOFs have pore structures ranging from micropores to mesopores. The periodicity and regularity of MOF active sites make it possible to design MOFs as high-precision catalysts. Zou et al. mentioned in the review that MOFs can form single-site catalysts [88]. Like the previously discussed carriers, MOFs demonstrate excellent performance following amination. In 2020, Ma et al. reported a catalyst prepared using a MOF as the carrier, with the average particle size of the loaded palladium atoms measured at only 2.3 nm. Additionally, the presence of amine groups extends the catalyst's lifespan [37]. It is worth noting that in 2020, Zou et al. reported the preparation of a catalyst using dual carriers. They found that the addition of a second MOF effectively prevented small Pd from accumulating near the MOF fiber structure during the dehydrogenation process [94]. So far, there are few reports on this kind of dual carriers, but the research shows that this approach is feasible. It provides ideas and directions for the future development of FAD catalysts. In summary, each material used as a carrier has its advantages. Selecting the appropriate material and applying suitable modification strategies can maximize catalyst effectiveness. Amine group modification is highly effective in FAD. Additionally, new optimization strategies have been reported in recent years. In 2023, Li et al. combined porous carbon and silica to prepare a composite C-SiO2 carrier. The role of SiO2 is to mitigate the agglomeration and deactivation issues of palladium based catalysts [95].This section introduces both organic and inorganic carriers, among which carbon carriers are the most widely used. Resin, as an emerging carrier, is also very effective. Compared with carbon carriers, it can be easily prepared and shaped to meet test needs. The advantage of MOFs is the combination of metals and organic ligands. 2.1.3 Promoter strategy Adding additives is a common method to increase hydrogen production. The addition of promoters such as rare earth elements, acid/base compounds, and organic compounds can promote the FAD. In liquid-phase reaction systems, it is very common to add sodium formate as a reaction accelerator. In Table 1, sodium formate is used as a promoter in several reactions [28,35]. During decomposition, FA is first broken down into formate anions. Adding sodium formate facilitates this step and can significantly influence the reaction's extent. While sodium formate enhances FAD, high concentrations may inhibit the reaction. Wang et al. provided an explanation for the catalytic effect of sodium formate on the reaction [96]. Sodium formate can be used not only as an accelerant but also as a reducing agent. A proposed hypothesis suggests that sodium formate reacts with H2O to produce H2. Additionally, from the perspective of inhibiting side reactions, H₂O can be considered an additive, as its presence hinders the dehydration of FA. Therefore, in liquid-phase reactions, the system typically consists of FA, sodium formate, and H₂O. The gas-phase reaction differs from the liquid-phase reaction, so sodium formate cannot be used as an additive. Bulushev et al. demonstrated for the first time that cucurbituril (CB6) acts as a gas phase decomposition agent for FA [48]. The reaction was carried out at a lower temperature with the addition of CB6. Another effect of CB6 is to direct the hydrogen atoms in FA, making H2 easier to synthesize. CB6, as an organic marker, is the first to be used as an assistant in FAD. Boron is also commonly used as an additive. Studt et al. conducted a theoretical study on the effect of boron as an additive on FAD [97]. The activation energy on the surface of palladium atoms can be altered due to the presence of boron. This allows reaction intermediates to easily access the active sites on palladium. The promoter strategy is highly effective in both gas-phase and liquid-phase reactions. Sodium formate, as the most common additive, is not only easy to obtain but also very convenient to add to the reaction. Unlike previous modification strategies, the promoter strategy is simple to implement and offers a diverse selection of additives. It is expected that more additives will be used in FAD in the future. 2.1.4 Structure design strategy In addition to using bimetallic systems and changing the carrier to improve catalyst performance, the effect of the catalyst structure has also been studied. Core-shell structure of catalysts could enhance metal dispersion and increase the specific surface area of catalysts. Moreover, the core-shell mechanism provides controllable morphology and compositional structure. The continued development of core-shell catalysts can significantly improve the efficiency of FAD. Currently, most known core-shell catalysts are synthesized based on bimetallic systems, such as palladium–silver core-shell catalysts and palladium–cobalt core-shell catalysts. In addition, there are core-shell catalysts with single metal atoms as the core and other materials as the shell, such as those with gold atoms as the core. In 2022, Tsang et al. reported a method for preparing Pd–Ag bimetallic core-shell nano catalysts with synergistic ligand and silver strain effects. The catalysts prepared by this method allow for control of core composition and shell thickness. The presence of the shell can effectively prevent the reduction of activity in the inner metal core [98]. Liu et al. reported a cellulose-derived Pd–Ag core-shell catalyst with a TOF of 2875 h−1 at 333 K. The catalyst uses biomass-derived materials as feedstock, effectively maximizing resource utilization [99]. Han et al. also reported on the study of a Pd–Ag core-shell catalyst ( Fig. 4). The octahedral Pd–Ag alloy core was prepared by a one-pot method, with palladium used as the catalyst shell. They concluded that the high conversion efficiency of the catalyst was due to the optimal combination of the electron promoting effect and lattice strain effect of Ag on Pd (Fig. 4b,c). The catalytic performance is affected by the thickness of the shell (Fig. 4e) [100]. Unlike the bimetallic catalysts previously reviewed, this catalyst is designed with specific metal distribution and structure in mind, featuring one metal as the core and another as the shell. This design not only leverages the synergistic effects of the bimetals but also utilizes the spatial structure effectively. Besides using noble metals for core-shell structures, non-noble metals have also become a viable option. Liu et al. studied the structural role of Pd-Co@Pd core-shell catalysts. The core-shell structure utilizes the metal's ligand effect. The alloy core attracts the Pd shell, altering the electronic configuration of Pd. When the core-shell catalyst interacts with reactants, the structure promotes the segregation of Co atoms from the core into the Pd shell, ensuring reaction stability [101]. Santucci et al. investigated the performance of multinuclear and mononuclear catalysts. The core-shell structure not only ensures the exposure of active sites but also provides an insulating protective effect through the SiO2 shell [102]. The external silica shell prevented the leaching of internal metal particles, thereby extending the catalyst's service life. It can be observed that the most common material for the shell is SiO2, due to its orderly structure and dense pore configuration. Kegnæs found that the confinement effect of the silica shell increases the number of low-coordinated Au corner atoms, promoting the FAD [103]. Theoretically and based on experimental results, the advantages of optimizing catalyst structure are greater than those of the bimetal strategy. In general, the core-shell structure demonstrates excellent performance. The preparation process is straightforward: first, the metal core is prepared, and then it is encapsulated with the shell. Additionally, selecting a suitable shell can not only prevent the leaching of internal metal atoms but also block toxic substances generated during the reaction from entering the catalyst. Most importantly, this structure greatly increases the specific surface area of the catalyst, significantly enhancing its catalytic performance. 2.2 Catalyst deactivation In reactions using noble metals as catalysts, the processes can be divided into liquid-phase and gas-phase reactions based on different reaction conditions. In general, the reasons for catalyst deactivation differ between the two types of reactions. This section reviews catalyst deactivation phenomena from the perspective of two reaction phases. In liquid-phase reaction systems, the concentration of reactants, additives, temperature, and products can all contribute to catalyst deactivation. Quintanilla et al. found that independently varying the initial reactant concentration, additives, and reaction temperature affects both the reaction rate and catalyst deactivation [104]. Meanwhile, Hu et al. [105] and Quintanilla et al. [104] both found that the primary cause of catalyst deactivation is the occupation of active sites. The primary substances occupying the active sites are protons, H₂O, and HCOO intermediates. When protons and H₂O occupy the active sites, CO₂ stabilization on the catalyst surface is promoted. Catalyst activity is also affected by temperature, as high temperatures can trigger phase transitions in the metal components, thereby impacting their catalytic performance. Additionally, catalyst deactivation is related to changes in the valence state of the active components, as variations in reaction temperature and the presence of products can cause alterations in the metal's valence state. Quintanilla et al. [104] reported that one of the causes of catalyst deactivation is the significant loss of Pd²⁺ after changes in reaction temperature. Understanding the mechanisms of deactivation is essential for developing specific strategies to prevent catalyst deactivation. In gas-phase reaction systems, catalysts can also be poisoned by CO. Sobolev et al. found that when the catalyst carrier is acidic, FA tends to decompose into H₂O and CO [45]. Therefore, it can be inferred that controlling the acidic and basic sites on the carrier can direct the pathway of FAD. Kegnæs et al. used a catalyst to produce hydrogen at a high temperature and found that the catalyst became deactivated [47]. Analysis of the catalyst characterization revealed that at high temperatures, metal sintering occurred on the catalyst, leading to a rapid reduction in active sites and ultimately resulting in catalyst deactivation. Generally, CO is produced by the hydrolysis of FA, and its production can be reduced by inhibiting this reaction, which is significantly influenced by the acidity or alkalinity of the environment. Metal leaching occurs due to the insufficient anchoring force of the carrier on the metal, allowing the metal to detach easily. In gas-phase reactions, high temperatures lead to metal sintering, reducing active sites. This irreversible phenomenon ultimately results in catalyst deactivation. 2.3 Mechanistic understanding of FAD It is well known that FAD proceeds via two main pathways: dehydration (Eq. 1) and dehydrogenation (Eq. 2) [106], represented by the following chemical equations: (1) HCOOH → CO + H 2 O (2) HCOOH → C O 2 + H 2 Studies show that the decomposition pathways of FA are summarized in Eq. (1) and Eq. (2), which generally describe the final decomposition products of FA. Many researchers have studied the intermediates of FAD and their transformation pathways. Due to the differences in reaction media, this section reviews the mechanisms of FAD in both liquid-phase and gas-phase systems. In liquid-phase reaction systems, the formate anion dehydrogenation pathway and the combinative desorption of hydrogen have been identified as the reaction pathway in the aqueous phase and the rate-determining step, respectively. Therefore, sodium formate is commonly added to liquid-phase reactions to promote the reaction. Kim et al. [107] investigated the formate anion dehydrogenation pathway. In the presence of an H₂O medium, FA spontaneously decomposes into HCOO⁻ and H⁺. The HCOO⁻ adsorbs onto the catalyst surface and further decomposes into CO₂ and H⁻. Finally, H⁺ and H⁻ combine to form H₂. Fig. 5 illustrates the molecular changes and the corresponding potential energy for each step. It is important to note that the HCOO⁻ decomposition step and the combination of H ions influence the overall reaction rate. Quintanilla et al. [104,108] studied the effect of sodium formate on FAD. The presence of sodium formate reduces the activation energy of FAD. The above outlines the decomposition mechanism of FA in liquid-phase reactions. In gas-phase reaction systems, due to the absence of an H₂O medium, FA directly interacts with the catalyst to undergo the reaction. Dehydrogenation of FA occurs mainly through two pathways: (1) direct decomposition of COOH* (HCOOH* ↔ HCOOHpa* ↔ COOH* + H* ↔ CO2* + 2H* ↔ CO2 + H2) and (2) CO*-assisted decomposition of COOH* (HCOOH* (+CO*) ↔ HCOOHpa* (+CO*) ↔ COOH* + H* (+CO*) ↔ CO2* + H* + COH* ↔ CO2* + 2H* (+CO*) ↔ CO2 + H2 (+CO*), whereby (+CO*) denotes spectator CO*). Mavrikakis et al. [109] proposed the FAD mechanism model on palladium and platinum catalysts ( Fig. 6a,c). From the figure, breaking the C–H bond in HCOOH* to generate H* is the most direct step in producing H2. HCOOH* and HCOOHpa* are formed simply due to their different conformations when bound to the active site. COOH* intermediates produce CO2* and CO* depending on how the bonds break. The pathway that produces CO* also produces OH*, which combines with H* to form H2O. The mechanism of FAD can be intuitively understood through the reaction path. Fig. 6b,d show the potential energy diagrams of FA on Pd (100) and Pt (100), respectively. The potential energy diagrams indicate that the highest transition state (TS) in the COOH pathway corresponds to the transformation of HCOOH, with an energy of 0.34 eV, while the highest-TS step in the HCOO pathway is the dehydrogenation of HCOO, associated with an energy of 0.17 eV [110]. Through the microdynamic model of the two different metals, it can be observed that the intermediate products of FAD are similar, but the energy required for each reaction step differs. This variation may be related to the active sites of the metals. 3 Non-noble metal catalyst Recently, non-noble metal catalysts have gradually attracted widespread attention. Modification strategies are essential for non-noble metal catalysts due to the inherently lower activity of non-noble metals compared to noble metals. It has been found that transition metals such as nickel, cobalt, copper, and molybdenum carbide can be used as catalysts [111]. Enthaler et al. reported the use of a nickel catalyst for the conversion of FA into H₂ and CO₂. The catalyst shows good catalytic activity, indicating that nickel catalysts could serve as an alternative to noble metal catalysts [112]. In addition, molybdenum carbide-based catalyst catalysts have attracted great attention. Molybdenum carbide not only has a high melting temperature, high hardness, and high tensile strength but also exhibits high electrical and thermal conductivity similar to ceramics [113]. Many studies show that molybdenum carbon-based catalysts can replace noble metal catalysts due to their excellent properties. Therefore, molybdenum carbon-based catalysts are being explored for application in FAD. Solymosi reported the successful use of a Mo2C catalyst to catalyze FAD in the gas phase [114]. Non-noble metals have lower coordination ability compared to noble metals, which means that most non-noble metal catalysts require higher temperatures to achieve optimal catalytic performance. For example, nickel-based catalysts exhibit excellent thermal stability, making them highly suitable for gas-phase reaction. Recently, a series of novel catalysts has been developed, such as molybdenum carbide-based catalysts and nickel-cobalt bimetallic catalysts. These catalysts have demonstrated high catalytic activity at room temperature, making them suitable for liquid-phase reactions. The more common non-noble metal catalysts are summarized in Table 3. 3.1 Catalyst modification strategy 3.1.1 Bimetallic strategy Since the bimetallic strategy is effective for noble metal catalysts, it can also be applied to the modification of non-noble metal catalysts. As early as 1982, E. IGLESIA and M. BOUDART reported on Ni–Cu catalysts and conducted a simple chemical determination of their properties [129]. Although the performance of copper catalysts is poor, they become effective when used as a secondary metal in catalysts. Dongil et al. [130] prepared a series of Ni–Cu catalysts using different carbon nanostructures as carriers. The catalysts show high selectivity for H2 (94–98 %) while achieving a conversion rate of over 95 %. Faroldi et al. [119] prepared Ni–Cu catalyst and compared it with ordinary Ni and Cu catalysts. The performance of the bimetallic catalyst is significantly higher than that of the single metal catalysts. The second metal does not affect the size of the catalyst nanoparticles and promotes the selectivity of the catalyst towards H2. However, the proportion of the second metal must be considered, as it may affect the intermetallic synergies. In a recent report, Junge et al. [21] designed a Co–Cu catalyst. They found that varying the copper loading amount could affect the activity of the catalyst. Fig. 7 shows the synthesis process of Co/Cu-N-C catalyst and the related characterization of the catalyst. Fig. 7b shows the presence of single atoms and diatomic pairs on the catalyst. The diatomic pairs, confirmed to be composed of Co and Cu (Fig. 7e), are evenly distributed on the carbon carrier. The use of a sacrificial template method for catalyst preparation allows the metal to remain in an atomic state, uniformly distributed on the carrier. The presence of Cu attracts Co electrons, lowering the activation energy barrier of Co. In general, the bimetallic strategy improves the performance of the catalyst, but there is still a gap compared to noble metal catalysts. However, the limited number of non-noble metals available restricts the application of this strategy. Therefore, carrier replacement and promoter strategies have been studied to further enhance catalytic performance. 3.1.2 Carrier modification strategy 3.1.2.1 Carbon-based carrier Carbon-based carriers are widely used in the research of non-noble metal catalysts. Carbon materials as carriers can yield catalysts with various morphologies by altering the preparation conditions. Guan et al. [123] summarized that different carbon sources result in catalysts with varying nanostructures. The previous section reviewed the advantages of carbon-based carriers, particularly their high specific surface area, which can expose numerous active sites. This section reports an additional role of high specific surface area. Rodríguez-Ramos et al. [131] reported that high specific surface area graphite enhances the carburization process, ultimately influencing the phase transformation of metal components. The high specific surface area of carbon materials promotes the formation of stable β-Mo2C. Since non-noble metal catalysts are mostly used in gas-phase reactions, the modification strategies for carbon-based carriers primarily focus on atomic doping. In 2023, Bulusheva et al. [120] discovered the formation of N4 sites on N-doped carbon-based carriers ( Fig. 8). The appearance of these sites leads to the aggregation of metal components, resulting in the formation of small clusters. In the latest report, Bulusheva et al. found that different N-doping methods influence the formation of Ni nanoparticles [132]. It can be inferred that the nitrogen content may influence the formation of defect sites in the carrier. As a result, Carbon materials are extensively used because of the high specific surface area and well-developed porous structure. In the future, more carbon carriers with efficient structures will be used in FAD. 3.1.2.2 Silica-based carrier When silica-based carriers are used in gas-phase reaction systems, the role of high specific surface area is less significant. The acidic and basic sites of silica-based carriers have a greater impact on the reaction. Koyuncu et al. [116] found that catalysts with low specific surface area exhibited higher activity than those with high specific surface area. This was attributed to the lower Lewis acidity of the low specific surface area catalysts. Because SiO2 is resistant to high temperature, it is often selected as a carrier when the reaction conditions require high temperature. One advantage of selecting silica-based carriers is the simplicity of their preparation. Catalysts with silica-based carriers can be obtained through a straightforward one-pot method. Currently, research on non-noble metal catalysts is limited. Carbon materials are widely used as carriers, and studies on N-doped carbon-based carriers have been reviewed. Although other types of carriers have been explored, there are few reports on their further modification. It is anticipated that future research will develop unique modification strategies for gas-phase reaction systems, leading to the creation of high-performance catalysts. 3.1.3 Promoter strategy In addition to the two modification methods mentioned above, it has also been found that promoter strategies can alter the electronic structure, ion valence state, acidity and basicity sites, surface structure, and grain size, thereby affecting the activity of the catalyst [133]. It is well established that the decomposition of FA is related to pH. Under alkaline conditions, FA is more likely to produce H2 and CO2. Therefore, alkaline substances can be used as additives to adjust the pH. In 2019, B. Faroldi et al. [134] reported doping Ca into a catalyst to observe its catalytic performance. The results show that at 433 K, with 19.3 wt% Ca doping, the conversion rate to FA reaches 100 % ( Fig. 9e), and the selectivity to H2 reaches 92 % (Fig. 9f). The addition of Ca stabilizes the Ni particles on the SiO2 carrier, preventing sintering during the reaction and prolonging the service life of the catalysts. Additionally, the addition of Ca affects the acid-base properties of SiO2. Fig. 9a,b indicate that the addition of Ca does not affect the average particle size of the catalyst nanoparticles but stabilizes the Ni on the carrier. Fig. 9c,d confirm that Ca doping has the most significant impact on catalytic performance. Faroldi et al. [119] also doped Li, Na and K as additives into the catalyst. Through experimental comparison, the K-doped catalyst shows the highest activity, and the TOF reaches 0.0113 s−1 at 403 K. Akihiro Yoshida et al. [126] reported the effect of Na and S on the catalytic performance of a MoS2/Mo2C composite catalyst. The results show that the presence of S element can improve the catalytic activity of Mo-DAL. Additionally, the catalyst activity with Na doping is higher than that with S doping, and Na doping reduces the activation energy required for FAD. The addition of alkali metals enhances the catalytic effect, particularly the doping effects of Ca and K. In addition to alkaline substances, some special organic substances can also be used as additives. However, organic additives have been specifically reported in noble metal catalysts. Therefore, further research is needed on the use of organic compounds as additives in non-noble metal catalysts. 3.2 Catalyst deactivation Both noble and non-noble metals experience deactivation due to CO poisoning, which leads to a loss of catalytic activity. The primary reason for this deactivation is that CO occupies the active sites, preventing interaction with FA. This phenomenon has been previously discussed and will not be elaborated upon here. This section mainly discusses other factors that contribute to the deactivation of non-noble metal catalysts. From the summary of non-noble metals, most non-noble metal catalysts operate in gas-phase reaction systems, which require high reaction temperatures. Therefore, the reasons for catalyst deactivation at high temperatures must be considered. The catalyst may agglomerate at high temperatures, reducing the contact area with FA. Sehested et al. found that catalyst sintering usually occurs when a higher concentration of Ni is used [135]. Metals tend to agglomerate at high temperatures. This phenomenon leads to an increase in catalyst particle size, thereby reducing catalytic efficiency. This affects the distribution of active sites and ultimately leads to reduced catalyst activity. In addition to the effects of temperature and CO, the conversion rate of intermediates can also impact catalyst activity. When Ha et al. studied the action mechanism of FAD on molybdenum carbide catalyst, they concluded that the intermediate product (HCO*O*) might cause catalyst poisoning. The adsorption effectiveness is reduced due to the slow conversion of intermediate product (HCO*O*) [125]. The slow rate of intermediate conversion steps leads to a reduced utilization of active sites, which directly reflects the lower activity of the catalyst. Chen et al. also proposed that HCO*O* could block the entry and exit of substances on the membranes [136], confirming the findings of Ha et al. In general, any slow step in the conversion of FA will lead to a decrease in the overall conversion rate. Therefore, it is essential to ensure that intermediates have a high conversion efficiency when they come into contact with active sites. In summary, although there are few reports on the deactivation of non-noble metal catalysts, it can be referred to the causes of the deactivation of noble metal catalysts in gas reactions. By adding certain additives, FA can be guided to decompose only into H2 and CO2, minimizing the interference of CO with the catalyst. Additionally, the amount of metal loading must be considered; excessive loading can lead to metal sintering, while insufficient loading can result in inadequate catalytic activity. Finally, the conversion efficiency of intermediates is also an important factor affecting catalyst activity. These are the potential causes of catalyst deactivation. 3.3 Mechanistic understanding of FAD In this section, the decomposition mechanism of FA is reviewed primarily through the gas-phase reaction system. The mechanism of FAD has been deeply understood through kinetic analysis and modeling. The ideal decomposition route is HCOOH → HCOO* + H* → CO2 + H* + H* → CO2 + H2. Giorgi [137] and Bashiri et al. [138] reported that during FAD, HCOO* and H* intermediates are present. The adsorption rate of FA is the key step that controls the overall reaction rate. Therefore, adjusting the adsorption rate of FA on active sites can enhance the overall reaction rate. The specific reaction pathway of FAD was reported in the literature, and the reasons affecting the reaction rate were explained. It was observed that FA molecules break bonds to produce intermediates and then form new ones. Ha et al. [125] studied the mechanism of FAD on a Mo2C catalyst and established an overall reaction mechanism model ( Fig. 10). They proposed that FAD follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood surface catalytic mechanism (Fig. 10b), where bidentate formate surface species (HCO*O*) are converted to monodentate formate (HCOO*) and subsequently undergo dehydrogenation. Increasing the reaction temperature is more conducive to the conversion of HCO*O*, thereby improving the overall reaction rate. The simulation results (Fig. 10c-g) agree with the proposed reaction mechanism. The figure illustrates the decomposition and recombination process of FA molecules. In addition to the earlier suggestion that FA adsorption affects the reaction rate, it is also proposed that temperature could influence the adsorption and transformation of intermediates. The model is built to visualize the pathway of FAD, the breaking of chemical bonds, and the combination of molecules during product synthesis. The energy required for each reaction step can be obtained through computational analysis, and a potential energy diagram can be drawn based on the calculation results. In 2018, Bashiri et al. [139] reported using dynamic Monte Carlo simulation to study the mechanism and kinetics of FAD on Ni (100). They demonstrated the decomposition path of FA with a model that included several intermediates: formic anhydride, HCOO, COOD, and HCO ( Fig. 11b). Benziger et al. [140] also reported that FA could decompose into methyl anhydride on Ni, further confirming the validity of Bashiri et al. 's model. In summary, it can be observed that the formation of H2 and CO2 from FA requires multiple steps and the conversion of several intermediates. The presence of Ni lowers the energy required for these conversions, facilitating the reaction. In summary, the mechanism of FAD on non-noble metal catalysts is being thoroughly investigated and analyzed. By labeling the H atoms in FA, the specific conversion pathways of H can be determined. Through simulation experiments, the optimal pathway for the decomposition of FA into H2 and CO2 can be identified. Understanding the types of reaction intermediates allows for the development of specialized catalysts targeting these intermediates. 4 Conclusion and prospective outlook With the increasing demand for energy, hydrogen is gradually being utilized as an alternative energy carrier. Owing to the high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen capacity, FA is a promising hydrogen storage medium. The FAD is promoted by catalysts. In this paper, the noble metal catalyst and non-noble metal catalyst are summarized and discussed respectively. The modification and application of noble metal catalysts such as Pd, Au, Ag and Pt were introduced. Catalysts such as Ni, Co, Mo2C and Cu are highlighted in non-noble metals. The results show that the structure design strategy is better than the bimetallic strategy. The structure optimization strategy is only applied to noble metal catalysts. The diversity of carriers provides additional options, especially the resin and MOF. Promoter strategy is the traditional modification strategy, and alkaline substances are considered the most. CO is the primary factor causing catalyst deactivation. The production of CO can be avoided by adjusting the pH of the reaction environment. A low conversion rate of reaction intermediates can also lead to catalyst deactivation. Currently, the catalytic performance of FAD heterogeneous catalysts can be improved through the composition of active metals, catalyst supports, and structural design. However, developing stable and efficient FAD-supported catalysts remains a challenge. Future research could focus on Mo2C catalysts. Mo2C, which possesses a high electron density similar to that of Pd and Pt, exhibits significant catalytic activity and can potentially replace precious metal catalysts. The high strength of the C-Mo bonds ensures the structural stability of Mo2C catalysts. Additionally, Mo2C has low CO selectivity, meaning its active sites are less likely to adsorb CO, thus reducing the negative impact of CO on catalyst activity. It is hoped that high-performance Mo2C catalysts could be developed in the future. CRediT authorship contribution statement Xiucong Wang: Writing – review & editing, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen is a renewable energy carrier and one of the most competitive fuel options for the future. Formic acid, due to its high gravimetric and volumetric hydrogen capacities (4.4 wt% and 53 g H2·L−1), is a viable hydrogen carrier. Formic acid can undergo hydrogen release and storage reactions when subjected to suitable catalysts. This paper reviews heterogeneous catalysts for the dehydrogenation of formic acid, focusing on catalyst modification, catalyst deactivation, and the reaction mechanism of formic acid. The modification strategies enhance catalyst performance by influencing catalyst size, composition, and electronic configuration through synergistic effects between metals and interactions between the support and the metal. The active sites are blocked by CO produced from side reactions, leading to catalyst poisoning. By adding Mo and altering the reaction alkalinity, CO production can be reduced, thereby preventing catalyst poisoning. Currently, there are two main mechanisms for formic acid decomposition. One mechanism involves adsorption and decomposition via the formate anion. The other involves decomposition and reorganization through a formic acid ester intermediate. This review summarizes the research progress on heterogeneous catalysts and suggests that Mo2C catalysts should be a focus for further study.
